text: morning all, im looking for some advice when it comes to effectively batching up orders (place and cancels) within flumine. Now I have upped the number of trades + strategies I think I may be ineffectively sending updates to betfair (leading to latency from time to time, not confirmed yet but a hunch from looking at the logs ). I believe order packages are designed to combat this, by batching up from market orders from the market blotters (I am right in my understanding?). I am looking to better understand this process and how I could improve my code to prevent unnecessary extra messages to betfair. Does anyone have any advice / be able further explain the process and how it can be optimised ?

elements.text: morning all, im looking for some advice when it comes to effectively batching up orders (place and cancels) within flumine. Now I have upped the number of trades + strategies I think I may be ineffectively sending updates to betfair (leading to latency from time to time, not confirmed yet but a hunch from looking at the logs ). I believe order packages are designed to combat this, by batching up from market orders from the market blotters (I am right in my understanding?). I am looking to better understand this process and how I could improve my code to prevent unnecessary extra messages to betfair. Does anyone have any advice / be able further explain the process and how it can be optimised ?

text:
So a market update comes in and processed through all strategies, after this an order package is created which like say can have multiple orders to reduce the number of requests.

The number of orders shouldn’t increase latency, are you monitoring CPU / ram? AWS? And have you tried profiling? I use cprofilev, quickly show you anything that is slow.

elements.text: So a market update comes in and processed through all strategies, after this an order package is created which like say can have multiple orders to reduce the number of requests.
The number of orders shouldn’t increase latency, are you monitoring CPU / ram? AWS? And have you tried profiling? I use cprofilev, quickly show you anything that is slow.

text: hmm okay, I do need to further profile , which ill look into today. It can run for a few hours before it starts to struggle so could be a rare laggy update myside. Should I be setting the  conflate_ms parameter. If this is not set will this lead to each pull from the stream containing minimal market_books, therefore only a few orders are batched and more network trips?

text: Conflating will just reduce he number of updates from betfair which will reduce your CPU but it sounds like you have some dodgy code, profile and it will tell you instantly unless it’s a memory leak but again this will be in your code

text: Hey everyone, quick question regarding streaming: Is it allowed to run more than one streamer to subscribe to more than 200 markets? Or how do you guys overcome this constraint (if possible)?

elements.text: Hey everyone, quick question regarding streaming: Is it allowed to run more than one streamer to subscribe to more than 200 markets? Or how do you guys overcome this constraint (if possible)?

text: You can have 10 connections simultaneously

elements.text: You can have 10 connections simultaneously

text: You can have the limit increased to 1000 markets or removed entirely

elements.text: You can have the limit increased to 1000 markets or removed entirely

text: Have you seen the undocumented <https://github.com/liampauling/betfair/blob/master/examples/exampleracecard.py|raceCard> endpoint?

attachments.text:
```
import logging

import betfairlightweight


# setup logging
logging.basicConfig(level=<http://logging.INFO|logging.INFO>)  # change to DEBUG to see log all updates

# create trading instance (don't need username/password)
trading = betfairlightweight.APIClient("username", "password")

# race card login
trading.race_card.login()

# update
market_id = "1.133559518"

# race card request (provide list / returns list)
race_cards = trading.race_card.get_race_card(market_ids=[market_id])


print(race_cards)
for race_card in race_cards:
    print(
        race_card, race_card.prize, race_card.timeform_123_text
    )  # view resources or debug to see all values available

    for runner in race_card.runners:
        print(runner.name, runner.comment)


# results request (provide list / returns list of dictionaries)
results = trading.race_card.get_race_result(market_ids=[market_id])

print(results)
for result in results:
    print(result)

```
attachments.title: examples/exampleracecard.py
